Sentence: Plenty of newcomers — with names like hakia and Snap — are trying to beat Google at its own game.
In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
The gift of laptops loaded with Windows Vista is only the latest of Microsoft’s efforts to engage the technologically aware, and often anti-Microsoft, blogging community.
Costly Gift From Microsoft Is an Invitation to Blog
An anonymous computer programmer claims to have hacked the copy protection used in both the HD-DVD and Blu-ray high-definition DVD formats.
Studios’ DVDs Face a Crack in Security

As Google continues to outmaneuver its main search rivals, Yahoo and Microsoft, plenty of newcomers – with names like Powerset, hakia, ChaCha and Snap – are trying to beat the company at its own game.
And Wikia, a company started by a founder of Wikipedia, plans to develop a search engine that, like the popular Web-based encyclopedia, would be built by a community of programmers and users.
In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
Technology stocks began a rally in mid-July that lifted the Nasdaq by more than 18 percent by year-end.
But how long can the rally last?
A Sizzling Six Months for Technology Shares
Botnet programs and other malicious software largely take aim at PCs running the Microsoft Windows operating system, because Windows’ ubiquity makes it fertile ground for network-based attacks.
Tips for Protecting the Home Computer
Video game makers are shipping more consoles than expected, setting the stage for what may be a multiyear battle among Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo.
Console Sales Beat Goals, Makers’ Early Reports Say
Bill Gates unveiled a partnership with the Ford Motor Company to build Microsoft technology into several Ford models.
Microsoft and Ford Combine Products
When shopping for a new computer, what kind of graphics card will be necessary to run Microsoft’s Windows Vista?
Getting Graphic With Vista
The notion of a computer at the heart of every home gets a little bump with the multitasking Hewlett-Packard's $1,800 TouchSmart PC.
The Computer With a TV, and a Family's Virtual Bulletin Board
Microsoft has so far failed to fire the imagination of the buying public since the Zune digital music player’s release last fall.
Knock, Knock, Microsoft.
It’s SanDisk
Netflix is introducing a service to deliver movies and television shows directly to PCs, not as downloads but as streaming video.
Netflix to Deliver Movies to the PC
Going head-to-head with Microsoft is a risky business strategy, but investors in a mail server technology developer, PostPath are confident enough to give the company an additional $15 million.
The Series C financing for PostPath closed in late December and was led by a new investor, Jafco Ventures.
Two previous investors Matrix Partners and Worldview Technology Partners also participated in the financing, which brings the company’s total funding to $30 million.
PostPath has developed a Linux-based exchange server that integrates fully with Microsoft’s own Exchange server.
E-Mail Start-Up Gets Cash to Take on Microsoft
After a radical redesign, Microsoft's Word, Excel and PowerPoint applications are almost totally new programs.
Purging Bloat to Fashion Sleek Software
Major technology companies are consolidating their support into the Linux Foundation to help the operating system compete more effectively against Microsoft.
Group Formed to Support Linux as Rival to Windows
Isilon‘s successful initial public offering could inspire other midrange data-storage companies to make a similar move, The 451 Group suggests in a report.
The firm also predicts that other storage companies will get snapped up by acquirers such as Hewlett-Packard, Sun, or even longer shots such as Microsoft or fresh-out-of-bankruptcy SGI.
More Deals Likely in Storage Sector, Report Says
Microsoft reported strong sales but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.
Delays Limit Robust Sales at Microsoft
Can Microsoft thrive in a new digital era?
In the worldview of Steven A. Ballmer, the company’s chief executive,  failure is not an option.
Preaching From the Ballmer Pulpit
Skeptics were drowned out by the marketing campaign for Microsoft’s operating system on the eve of its arrival.
First the Wait for Microsoft Vista; Now the Marketing Barrage
Software vulnerabilities are bought and sold online, both by legitimate security companies and by thieves.
A Lively Market, Legal and Not, for Software Bugs
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  The Coast Guard is searching for a computer scientist from Microsoft who left for a daylong sailing trip off the coast of San Francisco on Sunday and did not return.
A Researcher for Microsoft Is Reported Missing at Sea
The quiet debut for Microsoft’s latest version of the Windows operating system reflects how the company’s influence has faded as the nature of computer software has changed.
Vista Arrives With Limited Fanfare
Silicon Valley’s best and brightest organized a concerted, high-tech effort to find a missing Microsoft researcher.
Silicon Valley’s High-Tech Hunt for Colleague
A picture caption last Sunday with an article about Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, misidentified one of two executives with whom he was meeting.

Mr. Ballmer, at left in the picture, was shown with Craig Bruya, center, the chief financial officer of the Microsoft Business Solutions division — not with Frank H. Brod, the company’s chief accounting officer.
(Christopher Liddell, Microsoft’s chief financial officer, was at right.
Correction
The Vista release did not generate anything close to the excitement created 12 years ago when Windows 95 was introduced.
Microsoft’s Vista Debut Wasn’t Nearly So ‘Wow’
Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder and Seattle-area billionaire, has agreed to buy back the Rose Garden Arena in Portland that he previously owned.
Mr. Allen is making the acquisition through his investment vehicle, Vulcan.

As part of the agreement, a subsidiary of Vulcan plans to purchase Portland Arena Management, which has held the notes to the Rose Garden since Mr. Allen put the facility into bankruptcy about three years ago.
Paul Allen Takes Back Rose Garden
Microsoft rebuffed a public appeal by Mikhail Gorbachev for its chairman, Bill Gates, to intervene on behalf of a Russian school principal charged with software piracy.
Microsoft Spurns Appeal to Intervene in Russian Piracy Case
EMI is said to have discussed proposals to sell unprotected files through an array of digital retailers, including Apple, Microsoft, Real Networks and Yahoo.
EMI May Sell Recordings Online With No Anti-Copying Software
If Exxon Mobil doesn’t learn to talk more straightforwardly about its beliefs, it will never stop being the world’s whipping boy.
Exxon Mobil Just Wants to Be Loved
When I turn on my computer I receive a message that includes “Windows Defender Application failed to initialize.” What can I do to fix this error?
Updating Windows Defender
Wall Street analysts are being too optimistic about sales of Windows Vista, Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, said on Thursday.
Microsoft Plays Down a Sales Lift From Vista
A provincial school headmaster was convicted of using pirated Microsoft software in school computers, but no penalty was imposed.
Russian Judge Dismisses Any Penalty in Piracy Case
Google will unveil communications and productivity software aimed at businesses that will be accessible over the Internet.
A Google Package Challenges Microsoft
The Microsoft Wireless Entertainment Desktop 7000 combines a Bluetooth keyboard and a rechargeable mouse.
How About a Mouse and Keyboard to Go With That Vista?
Sony bought video-sharing Web site Grouper in August.
Google picked up YouTube, the king of video sites, in October.
Now comes a report that Microsoft has taken a look at Revver, yet another venture-backed video-sharing startup.

CNET News.com reports that executives from Microsoft toured Revver’s Los Angeles headquarters last month to determine whether that company’s service could enhance Soapbox, Microsoft’s own, newly launched service.
YouTube Rival Catches Microsoft’s Eye
Microsoft was ordered by a federal jury to pay $1.52 billion in a patent dispute over the MP3 format.
MP3 Patents in Upheaval After Verdict
VMware is the early leader in a fast-growing market for virtual-machine software, putting it on a collision course with Microsoft.
A Software Maker Goes Up Against Microsoft
Regulators will have more time on their hands as the Bush administration rejected more oversight of the rapidly growing hedge fund industry.
Deals in Radio and Food; Remorse From an Airline
Talk that Microsoft might (or at least, should) acquire Yahoo has been going on for months.
On Monday, TheStreet.com’s Vishesh Kumar joined the chorus, writing that Google‘s continued encroachment on Microsoft’s territory might force the software giant’s hand.
Last week, Google, already the leader of the online search business, introduced an upgraded version of its applications suite, which directly targets Microsoft’s venerable Office product.
Google’s Moves Rekindle Microsoft-Yahoo Speculation
Microsoft says its purchase of Medstory is part of an effort to build a suite of tools and services related to health care.
Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine

Microsoft‘s drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled Monday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers.
Microsoft is buying Medstory, a small start-up in Foster City, Calif., for an undisclosed amount.
Its search software applies artificial intelligence techniques to medical and health information in medical journals, government documents and on the Internet.
Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine
Acer’s TravelMate 2480-2779 laptop costs about $550 and runs Vista without complaint.
A Laptop With Vista That Seems Just Like a Fully Upgraded PC
The European Commission said Microsoft was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system.
Europeans Threaten More Fines for Microsoft

The European Commission on Thursday threatened Microsoft with millions of euros in new fines in a long-running antitrust dispute, saying the company was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system.

The commission issued a “statement of objections,” asking Microsoft to respond to a complaint that it was still not complying with a decision three years ago that the company had abused its dominant market position.
Europeans Threaten More Fines for Microsoft

Microsoft could jumpstart its online business through a purchase of Web giant Yahoo , but such a deal could also “open the door to potentially unmanageable risks,” analysts at UBS said in a report Thursday.
The analysts are just the latest to consider whether Microsoft should buy Yahoo.
Speculation about such a deal has only increased with Google‘s recent moves deeper into the software business.
More Analysis of a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
The $1.5 billion settlement against Microsoft is only one result of the music format’s tangled history.
Patent Fights Are a Legacy of MP3’s Tangled Origins
Microsoft plans to announce a contest to develop the next great digital diversion for the company’s Xbox 360.
Microsoft Prize of $10,000 to Promote Xbox Games
Trying to catch up with Google, Microsoft says it will change the way computer users search.
Searching for Michael Jordan?
Microsoft Wants a Better Way
The Microsoft executive who had led the effort to close the gap on Google is leaving the company.
Microsoft Executive Leaving

Microsoft said it had signed its first agreement to license its technology, almost three years after European Union antitrust regulators ordered the software company to share data to increase competition.

Microsoft said the deal, with Quest Software of California, was meant to comply with an antitrust order issued in March 2004 that demanded licensing of software that helps desktop computers communicate with servers.
But the deal was met with skepticism from adversaries, who questioned how a company with a longstanding relationship with Microsoft could be considered a rival.
The European Commission threatened Microsoft last week with fines as high as 3 million euros ($3.9 million) a day for failing to comply with the order.
Microsoft in First Technology License Deal

Microsoft is close to acquiring Tellme Networks, a privately held maker of products that bridge the worlds of speech recognition and the Internet, in a deal that could come as early as this week, according to CNet News.com.
Microsoft in Deal to Buy Tellme, Report Says
Xbox Live, Microsoft’s gaming network that serves some six million Xbox users, is scheduled to be opened to PC gamers on May 8.
Microsoft to Open Its Online Gaming Service to Windows Users
For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world.
John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them.

But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound “crazy”: a joint venture between the two companies to create a “search monetization” business.
Yet More Musings on a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
Confirming reports that it was close a deal, Microsoft said Wednesday that it would buy Tellme Networks, an speech-recognition technology company.
In a statement, Microsoft said that it plans to integrate Tellme’s products into its mobile offerings, with a long-term goal of integrating the technology into the rest of its lineup.
Microsoft to Buy Speech Technology Company
The deal to buy Tellme Networks was said to be worth more than $800 million, making it Microsoft’s biggest acquisition since 2002.
Microsoft Agrees to Buy Maker of Voice-Recognition Software
Microsoft researchers say they have traced the companies and techniques behind thousands of spam Web pages.
Researchers Track Down a Plague of Fake Web Pages

Mitch Lasky, who as chief executive of Jamdat led the company to the top of the cellphone-games market, is leaving his post as head of Electronic Arts‘s mobile-games unit to join Benchmark Capital as a general partner.

The move suggests that Benchmark, a Silicon Valley venture firm that just celebrated the sale of portfolio company Tellme Networks to Microsoft, will be considering more investments in gaming startups.
Benchmark Signals Gaming Plays With New Hire

Vulcan Capital, the venture-capital vehicle of Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, is creating a joint venture with Bankers’ Capital Group to look for investments in the banking sector in the southeast United States.
Bankers’ Capital was launched last year by a group of executives that cleaned up troubled bank Flag Financial and sold it to RBC Centura, the Financial News reports.
Paul Allen’s Firm to Seek Banking Investments
More by David Pogue on the early attempts to bridge the gulf between computer and TV.
Bridging the Computer-to-TV Divide
The new version is an appeal to an elite class of hard-core game players who would like a little more of everything.
Upgraded Version of Xbox 360 to Be Introduced by Microsoft

DoubleClick, an online advertising company controlled by a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, is exploring a sale and is in talks with potential suitors including Microsoft, the Wall Street Journal reported.
DoubleClick was publicly traded in 2005 when it agreed to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman for about $1.1 billion.
The firm is hoping to get at least $2 billion in a DoubleClick sale, a source told the Journal.
DoubleClick Said to Consider Sale
What is a high-definition multimedia interface?
A New Cable to Connect
Companies like Microsoft are filing lawsuits against outfits they say engage in a practice called “domain swiping.”
The Name Game (Plus Typos)

For Chatting Face to Face, Webcams With a Clearer View
Microsoft’s new program to pay companies to use its search engine brings an entirely new approach to acquiring customers: buying them at wholesale, instead of retail.
If at First You Don’t Succeed, Write a Check
A Wired magazine reporter was accidentally sent a memorandum written by the company’s public relations firm to coach Microsoft executives on how to handle his questions.
A Misfired Memo Shows Close Tabs on Reporter
ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering.
Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions.
ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006.
It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.
Web Measurement Firm ComScore to Go Public

If Google and Microsoft are circling DoubleClick — a bidding feud that has been reported but never acknowledged by any of the parties — it may be based partly on a new initiative that the online advertising firm announced Wednesday.
DoubleClick May Entice Buyers With Ad Exchange
The Windows Live Messenger will be available on the Xbox 360, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television.
Microsoft Brings Instant Chat to TV Screen, Through Games
The new chief executive for Corbis is expected to respond to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its sales.
A Photo Trove, a Mounting Challenge
Look out Bill Gates, here comes Carlos Slim Helu.
The Mexican telecoms mogul has breezed past Warren Buffett and is gaining on the Microsoft co-founder on the list of the world’s richest men, according to Forbes.
Mexican Midas Edges Out Oracle of Omaha on Forbes List
Google agreed to its largest acquisition Friday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick for almost double what it paid for YouTube last year.
Google Buys an Online Ad Firm for $3.1 Billion
Requesting the coveted H-1B visa, from India to Silicon Valley.
Parsing the Truths About Visas for Tech Workers
Microsoft contends that Google’s $3.1 billion deal to buy DoubleClick would hurt competition in the online advertising market.
Microsoft Urges Review of Google-DoubleClick Deal
Is Microsoft‘s objection to Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for online advertising company DoubleClick just a case of sour grapes?
Microsoft and AT&T, both veteran defendants of epic antitrust battles in the United States and Europe, is urging regulators to consider scuttling Google’s plan to buy DoubleClick.
Microsoft Urges Review of Google-DoubleClick Deal
Google‘s $3.1 billion acquisition of online advertising firm DoubleClick drove up shares of other Internet ad firms.
What was behind the rise?
Many investors were betting that Microsoft (which was reportedly also in the running for DoubleClick) and Yahoo would be driven to make deals of their own to keep up with Google.
DoubleCick Deal Puts Spotlight on Rivals
When I turn on my Windows XP computer, the folder C:\windows\system32 opens automatically every time.
Why is this and how do I stop it?
Closing a Stubborn Folder
Microsoft plans to offer a stripped-down version of Windows, Office and other software for $3 to people in developing nations.
Software by Microsoft Is Nearly Free for the Needy
Transferring files is one thing, but software is another matter altogether.
Moving Day for That Vista Machine
The company’s core search and advertising business continued to outpace that of Microsoft and Yahoo.
Profits Up 69% at Google, Exceeding Expectations
Google, Microsoft and Yahoo have trained their sights on cellphones as the next great battleground in the Internet search wars.
Big Money in Little Screens
PC video game titles, once the mainstay of video gaming, are showing signs of a comeback.
PC Games, Once Down, Show Signs of Rebound
Microsoft filed documents defending its demand to be paid royalties for releasing some software code to competitors.
Microsoft, Trying to Avoid a European Fine, Defends Demand for Royalties
Is there a way for two Treo 600 smartphones to synchronize with a single Microsoft Outlook profile?
Two Phones, One Calendar
Microsoft’s results suggested that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start.
Strong Quarter at Microsoft, and an Upbeat ’08 Outlook, Bring Wall St. a Sigh of Relief
AT&T had sued Microsoft, alleging that computers running Windows infringed on AT&T’s speech technology.
The ruling restricts the reach of patent holders overseas.
Supreme Court Sides With Microsoft in Patent Case
Microsoft has emerged as a contender to buy the online advertising firm 24/7 Real Media in an effort to stay competitive with online rivals Google and Yahoo, The New York Post reported Tuesday.
Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that Microsoft is considering a bid of about $1 billion, a hefty premium over the $600 million value that analysts have given the firm.
Microsoft Is Said to Consider a Bid for 24/7
Microsoft and Yahoo are in talks about a joint venture or some other form of cooperation, according to people briefed on the talks.
The discussions are part of a continuing dialogue that the two companies have been holding for more than a year, but are still in preliminary stages, these people say.
Microsoft in Early Talks With Yahoo
Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google.
Rumors Fly on Microsoft and Yahoo
Bill Gates spoke to marketers and advertising agencies in Seattle amid rumblings about a deal between Microsoft and Yahoo.
Gates Discusses Software, but Talk of a Yahoo Deal Persists
The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.
Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site
Windows Mobile 6 is now available as a free download for owners of the T-Mobile Dash.
Windows Upgrade for Smartphones Improves Search and E-Mail Features
Microsoft said Wednesday that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by Tribune, Gannett and McClatchy.
The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.
Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site

The online marketing firm 24/7 Media on Wednesday disclosed that it has hired Lehman Brothers to help it assess “strategic alternatives,” adding credence to rampant speculation that the company is up for sale.

The New York Post reported this week that both WPP Group, the London-based advertising and marketing group, and software gaint Microsoft were “leading contenders” to buy 24/7, which has a market capitalization of about $560 million.
24/7 Media Confirms Hiring Investment Bank
A computer engineer from India wants to help schools in his homeland.
A Microsoft Alumnus Shares His Good Fortune
Even as rumors swirl that Yahoo might be heading for some kind of deal with Microsoft, the Internet giant has picked a technology deal maker as its next chief financial officer.
Yahoo announced Tuesday that it had hired Blake J. Jorgensen, a co-founder of the technology-focused investment bank Thomas Weisel Partners, as its finance chief.
He will succeed Susan L. Decker, who took control of the company’s advertising operations in December amid mounting competition from its archrival Google.
Yahoo Hires Thomas Weisel Co-founder as Finance Chief
The company is hoping that Halo 3 will increase the Xbox 360’s momentum in the gaming market.
Microsoft to Release New Version of Halo Video Game on Sept. 25
In a new approach, citations from news reports, images and video will be combined in results of a single query.
Google’s One-Stop Search to Yield Text and Images
Microsoft said Friday it would buy aQuantive, an online advertising firm, for $66.50 a share in cash.
The deal, valued at $6 billion, was easily Microsoft’s largest acquisition ever and the price represented an eye-popping 85 percent premium to aQuantive’s closing price Thursday.
Microsoft Pays Up for Online Advertising Firm aQuantive

Whether it was because of sheer luck or an inside tip, options traders made some big bets on aQuantive on Thursday — just in time to cash in on the company’s $6 billion deal to be acquired by Microsoft.

Trading in aQuantive’s options has been active for weeks, driven in part by the rampant takeover speculation surrounding many independent Web advertising firms since Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick in mid-April.

But according to Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, activity in aQuantive’s call options went through the roof on Thursday, with a volume of 9,363 contracts, or more than five times the average volume on the previous five days.
Before the aQuantive Deal, Lots of Well-Timed Trades
Microsoft had about $28 billion in cash and short-term investment on March 31, an amount the CIA World Factbook tells us is more than twice the gross domestic product of Iceland.
But despite its riches, the software giant has shied away from large acquisitions, especially in the past five years or so.
That is part of the reason Friday’s $6 billion cash bid for online advertising company aQuantive was so surprising.
(The 85 percent premium it agreed to pay was something of a shock as well.)
Microsoft: Tight-Fisted No More?
The plan to purchase aQuantive for $6 billion, at an 85 percent premium, comes after acquisitions of other firms by WPP Group, Google and Yahoo.
Microsoft to Buy Online Ad Company
Microsoft’s $6 billion acquisition of aQuantive signaled its struggle to build an Internet ad business on its own.
Internet Giants Vie to Snap Up Web Ad Firms
The people behind Firefox have a dilemma: What happens when an open-source project starts to become successful?
Firefox and the Anxiety of Growing Pains

Corporate takeovers helped spur the Dow Jones industrial average to its 24th record close this year on Friday, even as the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index came within striking distance of its record high.

The latest takeover news, including deals involving marquee names like General Electric and Microsoft, signaled that the enormous amount of liquidity that has lubricated global stock markets in recent months is still in good supply.
“The M.& A. activity and earnings seem to be holding up better than expected.
I think you’re going to see more of this,” Bill Dwyer, chief investment officer at MTB Investment Advisors, told The Associated Press.
M&A Extends Markets’ Bull Run
With an agreement to buy aQuantive under its belt, Microsoft is playing down rumors — in the air for at least a year, most recently stoked by the New York Post — that it might try to buy Yahoo.

“We have all of the pieces we need to move forward” in the online-advertising business, Yusuf Mehdi, Microsoft’s chief advertising strategist, said Wednesday at a Goldman Sachs  Internet conference in Las Vegas.
Microsoft: We Don’t Need Yahoo

As competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields intensifies, companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo frequently find themselves going after the same candidates, as well as running up against myriad Silicon Valley start-up companies that have been pumped up with venture capital in recent years.
To Lure Top Talent, Google Finds Novel Ways to Recruit
Microsoft plans to unveil a new computing device called Surface, featuring a 30-inch screen embedded in an acrylic tabletop.
Touch Screen in a Table Is the Latest Wrinkle in Computers
Google will make applications like Gmail and Docs and Spreadsheets available offline, in a move that will challenge Microsoft.
Moving Web-Based Software Offline
Bill Gates and Steven P. Jobs appeared in public to relive old battles and speculate about the future of digital culture and technology.
For Jobs and Gates, a Night to Reminisce
Microsoft's version of the multi-touch computer adds one very cool, though impractical, twist: interaction with other electronics.
Much Ado About Microsoft's Surface Computer
In the battle between Apple and Microsoft, two men are in charge of competing efforts to ensure that the PC’s basic software stays relevant in a Web-centered world.
Competing as Software Goes to Web
Microsoft said Thursday it had acquired Stratature, a privately held company that specializes in so-called master data management software.
Through the acquisition, Microsoft will build master data management tools into its Office System line.
Microsoft Picks Up Data Management Firm
A company the government once tried to break up has been repeatedly defended by the Bush administration against charges of anticompetitive conduct.
Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Dept.
Sony has a long and colorful history of failure on the Internet, but there has been a bright spot.
Sony’s Other Games Division Makes Push in New Direction
Several Internet companies, including Microsoft and eBay, are working on new ways to keep spammers from infiltrating their sites.
A Dog or a Cat?
New Tests to Fool Automated Spammers
General Electric’s NBC unit and Microsoft explored making a joint bid for Dow Jones but decided against it a week ago, a person close to NBC and Microsoft said.
NBC Studied Dow Jones Bid With Microsoft

Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google.
Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Department
General Electric‘s NBC unit and Microsoft explored making a joint bid for Dow Jones but decided against it about a week ago, according to news reports Monday.
NBC Studied Dow Jones Bid With Microsoft
A Windows-based Safari Web browser opens a new front in Apple's rivalry with Microsoft.
Apple Releasing a Windows Browser

The family that controls Dow Jones is preparing to submit a new set of proposals to News Corporation on how to protect The Wall Street Journal’s editorial independence in a potential sale, The Journal reported.

Separately, The Times of London, which is owned by News Corporation, reported Tuesday that General Electric is still considering an offer for Dow Jones after talks of a joint bid with Microsoft broke down.
Bancrofts Said to Prepare New Proposal for Murdoch
The success of young entrepreneurs is rooted in the commercial, competitive, nonegalitarian and open nature of American society.
The Loose Reins on U.S. Teenagers Can Produce Trouble or Entrepreneurs
Michael S. Dell sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19.
Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard sophomore at the time.

A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.
Today’s Teens, Today’s Entrepreneurs
The Federal Trade Commission reportedly wants to take a look at a few online advertising acquisitions, not just Google‘s planned deal to acquire DoubleClick.
Microsoft and Yahoo Deals to Come Under Scrutiny, Report Says
Microsoft will take a stake in Shanghai-listed Changhong Electric and work with the firm to jointly develop entertainment products that can be accessed via the Internet, Changhong said.
Changhong Electric said in a statement on Monday that Microsoft would take a 94-million-yuan ($12.3 million) stake in the firm by purchasing 15 million new shares.
Microsoft Takes Stake in Chinese Game Maker

After making an overture to Microsoft about a joint bid for Dow Jones, the General Electric Company, the parent of NBC, is now exploring that idea with Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, according to reports on Monday.
The talks are still preliminary, and Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion offer for Dow Jones represents a “a very high threshold,” The New York Times said.
The Wall Street Journal quoted several sources describing the possibility of a deal as a “long shot.”
G.E.
and Pearson Explore Bid for Dow Jones
The changes are in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of the operating system is anticompetitive.
Microsoft to Alter Windows Vista
It’s become a monthly ritual with few surprises.
Web audience measuring firms report numbers for Web search traffic in the United States.
Yahoo does well.
Google does a lot better.
Microsoft and others barely hold on, or worse.
Yahoo Good, Google Better (a Lot Better)
The fumbling of Google’s largest challengers has not dampened the enthusiasm of entrepreneurs and venture capitalists for entering the search game.
The Human Touch That May Loosen Google’s Grip
How far will Google, Microsoft, Yahoo or other Internet powerhouses go in their effort to dominate digital advertising, the fastest-growing part of the marketing business?
In Hot Ad Deal Environment, Are Big Agencies the Next Target?
Google is pressing for an extension to the Justice Department’s oversight of Microsoft‘s business practices, which for the most part is set to expire in November, according to a court filing Monday.
Google Seeks Ruling on Microsoft Oversight
Want to undo a whole bunch of changes in a Microsoft Word document — without having to repeatedly hit Control-Z (Command-Z on the Mac) to back up one change at a time?
Tip of the Week: Undoing Changes in Microsoft Word
Google loses a round against Microsoft in court, but takes another blow against one of Microsoft’s most sensitive areas: corporate e-mail.
Google v. Microsoft, In and Out of Court
The keyboard comes in jet black and has blue L.E.D.
backlights that cast an eerie glow through and around the keys.
A Keyboard Made for Those in Need of a ‘Kill Aliens’ Command
Circulating online, the thoughts of an employee who’s worked at both places, comparing the offices, pay and perks.
Google v. Microsoft: What’s the Better Workplace?
The decision by a blog-advertising network to deploy its writers to produce marketing copy for Microsoft and Cisco may have set back the efforts of professional bloggers to gain credibility.
Some Bloggers Blur Some Lines
Since November, Xbox LIVE Marketplace has offered video-on-demand downloads of movies and download-to-own episodes of television shows.
Xbox Offers a Forum to Reach Gamers Where They Live
A new report from IDC shows Microsoft and Oracle giving new competition to the leaders in this rapidly growing market.
Business Intelligence Software Grows Up
The stock surges for Local.com because it was granted two patents related to local searches and free, ad-supported 411 services.
It’s potentially a huge business that companies like Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and others are fighting to dominate.
Gunning for Licensing Rights to Local Search
Microsoft buys two data centers in California in its race to keep up with Google’s processing might.
Keeping Up With the Googlers
What makes Nokia’s N76 smartphone has a powerful processor and an operating system that lets it run a number of programs including one that reads Microsoft Office files.
Nokia, Without Fanfare, Introduces a Superphone Without Contract Obstacles

European Union regulators on Wednesday fined Telefónica, the Spanish telecommunications company, 151.85 million euros ($207.17 million), saying it had unfairly squeezed rivals by setting wholesale Internet access prices too high.
